SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Patent foramen ovale (PFO) has been associated with cryptogenic stroke in young patients
CLINICAL CASE: A 27-year-old man presented with acute confusional syndrome, altered language, bradypsychia and somnolence
Brain MRI showed symmetrical bilateral thalamic infarctions probably due to occlusion of Percheron's artery type 2b
CONCLUSIONS: Cerebrovascular disease is a frequent cause of disability and even death in young patients, and thus its medical approach should be emphasized
